measured_by: Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire
justification: “In this paper, we introduce and validate a novel psychometric tool to characterise individual differences in ways of knowing—the Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire.”

measured_by: Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire – Expert Authority subscale
justification: “In Study 1, we identified six factors—Expert Authority, Reason, Intuition, Personal Experience, Faith, and Culture—each representing a separate knowledge foundation.”

measured_by: Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire – Reason subscale
justification: The six‐factor solution included a distinct “Reason” factor, indicating that the questionnaire separately measures reliance on logical reasoning as a way of knowing.

measured_by: Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire – Intuition subscale
justification: Among the six factors extracted from the questionnaire items was an “Intuition” factor, capturing trust in gut feelings as a knowledge source.

measured_by: Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire – Personal Experience subscale
justification: The EFA revealed a “Personal Experience” factor, and additional items were created to complete this subscale within the Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire.

measured_by: Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire – Faith subscale
justification: Faith emerged as one of the six knowledge foundations assessed by the new questionnaire, reflecting reliance on religious or spiritual sources.

measured_by: Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire – Culture subscale
justification: A separate “Culture” factor was retained, measuring trust in culturally transmitted knowledge within the questionnaire.

measured_by: Epistemic Pluralism Scale
justification: “We created a scale to examine whether those who agree with the idea of epistemic pluralism also score highly on multiple factors in the Foundations of Knowledge Questionnaire.”

measured_by: Trust in Science and Scientists Scale (TSSS)
justification: “This is a self-report scale devised by Nadelson et al. (2014) to quantify trust in the scientific process and the credibility of scientists.”

measured_by: Epistemic Orientation Short Scale – Rationalism subfactor
justification: The Epistemic Orientation Short Scale “contains three subfactors: rationalism, intuitionism, and empiricism,” used here to validate corresponding constructs.

measured_by: Epistemic Orientation Short Scale – Intuitionism subfactor
justification: The same Epistemic Orientation Short Scale includes an “intuitionism” subfactor to assess preference for intuitive ways of knowing.

measured_by: Epistemic Orientation Short Scale – Empiricism subfactor
justification: The EOSS also measures an “empiricism” subfactor, capturing reliance on observational evidence.

measured_by: Religious Commitment Inventory (RCI)
justification: “This is a 10-item self-report measure created by Worthington et al. (2003) to measure adherence to religious values, beliefs, and practices.”

measured_by: HEXACO Openness to Experience Scale
justification: “The Openness to Experience subscale assesses a preference for novel experiences and appreciation of art, emotion, adventure, and unusual ideas.”

measured_by: Rational-Experiential Inventory – Need for Cognition subscale
justification: The Rational-Experiential Inventory “measures analytic … thinking styles” via the Need for Cognition (NFC) subscale.

measured_by: Rational-Experiential Inventory – Faith in Intuition subscale
justification: The same inventory includes the Faith in Intuition (FI) subscale, “capturing an orientation to intuitive thinking.”

measured_by: Reynolds Social Desirability Scale
justification: “This scale measures a tendency to respond in a socially desirable way to survey questions,” using Reynolds’ 13-item questionnaire.

measured_by: Satisfaction with Life Scale (SWLS)
justification: “This scale measures global life satisfaction (Diener et al., 1985) and includes five items.”

measured_by: Cognitive Reflection Test (CRT)
justification: “The CRT is a problem-solving task designed to measure the tendency to override immediate, intuitive but incorrect responses … and reflect further to find a correct answer.”

measured_by: Epistemically Suspect Belief Scale (ESBS)
justification: “This scale is designed to measure belief in a range of epistemically suspect claims (Šrol, 2022).”

measured_by: Belief in Epistemically Implausible Claims (BEIC) Protocol
justification: “BEIC protocol. This protocol was used … to classify participants as either believers or non-believers of implausible claims (Martire et al., 2020).”
construct: classification as believer vs non-believer of implausible claims
